summary.para: Represents a 16-bit unsigned integer.

threadSafety.para: This type is safe for multithreaded operations.

content.para: The UInt16 value type represents unsigned integers with values ranging from 0 to 65535.

UInt16 provides methods to compare instances of this type, convert the value of an instance to its string representation, and convert the string representation of a number to an instance of this type.
For information about how format specification codes control the string representation of value types, see [<topic://cpConFormattingOverview>].

This type implements interfaces T:System.IComparable, T:System.IComparable`1, T:System.IFormattable, and T:System.IConvertible. Use the T:System.Convert class for conversions instead of this type's explicit interface member implementation of T:System.IConvertible.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or T:System.UInt16 and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified object and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: An object to compare, or null.

returnValue.para: A signed number indicating the relative values of this instance and value.

entry.para: This instance is less than value.
This instance is equal to value.
This instance is greater than value.

content.para: value is not a T:System.UInt16.
Any instance of T:System.UInt16, regardless of its value, is considered greater than null.
value must be null or an instance of T:System.UInt16; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The following code example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.CompareTo(System.Object) method.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or T:System.UInt16 and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified 16-bit unsigned integer and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: An unsigned integer to compare.

returnValue.para: A signed number indicating the relative values of this instance and value.

entry.para: This instance is less than value.
This instance is equal to value.
This instance is greater than value.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IComparable`1 interface and performs slightly better than the M:System.UInt16.CompareTo(System.Object) method because it does not have to convert the value parameter to an object.

Depending on your programming language, it might be possible to code a Overload:System.UInt16.CompareTo method where the parameter type has fewer bits (is narrower) than the instance type. This is possible because some programming languages perform an implicit widening conversion that represents the parameter as a type with as many bits as the instance.

For example, suppose the instance type is T:System.Int32 and the parameter type is T:System.Byte. The Microsoft C# compiler generates instructions to represent the value of the parameter as an T:System.Int32 object, then generates a M:System.Int32.CompareTo(System.Object) method that compares the values of the T:System.Int32 instance and the T:System.Int32 parameter representation.
Consult your programming language's documentation to determine whether its compiler performs implicit widening conversions on numeric types.
The following code example demonstrates generic and nongeneric versions of the Overload:System.UInt16.CompareTo method for several value and reference types.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified object or T:System.UInt16.
Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified T:System.UInt16 value.

content.para: A T:System.UInt16 value to compare to this instance.

returnValue.para: true if obj has the same value as this instance; otherwise, false.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IEquatable`1 interface, and performs slightly better than M:System.UInt16.Equals(System.Object) because it does not have to convert the obj parameter to an object.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified object or T:System.UInt16.
Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified object.

content.para: An object to compare to this instance.

returnValue.para: true if obj is an instance of T:System.UInt16 and equals the value of this instance; otherwise, false.

content.para: The following code example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.Equals(System.Object) method.

summary.para: Returns the hash code for this instance.
Returns the T:System.TypeCode for value type T:System.UInt16.
Represents the largest possible value of UInt16. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 65535; that is, hexadecimal 0xFFFF.

summary.para: Represents the smallest possible value of UInt16. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 0.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.
Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.

returnValue.para: A 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent to the number contained in s.

content.para: s is null.
s is not in the correct format.
s represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Items in square brackets ('[' and ']') are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: Optional white space.
An optional positive sign.
A sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9.

content.para: The s parameter is parsed using the formatting information in a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo initialized for the current system culture. For more information, see P:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo.CurrentInfo.
The following example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.
Converts the string representation of a number in a specified style to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.
A bitwise combination of T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles values that indicates the permitted format of s. A typical value to specify is F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.Integer.

returnValue.para: A 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent to the number specified in s.

content.para: s is null.
style is not a T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles value.
-or-
style is not a combination of F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier and F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.HexNumber values.
s is not in a format compliant with style.
s represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Or, if style includes F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier:
[ws]hexdigits[ws]
Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: Optional white space if permitted by style.
An optional sign.
A sequence of digits from 0 through 9.
A sequence of hexadecimal digits from 0 through f, or 0 through F.

content.para: The following example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number in a specified style and culture-specific format to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.
A bitwise combination of T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles values that indicates the permitted format of s. A typical value to specify is F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.Integer.
An T:System.IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information about s.

returnValue.para: A 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent to the number specified in s.

content.para: s is null.
style is not a T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles value.
-or-
style is not a combination of F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier and F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.HexNumber values.
s is not in a format compliant with style.
s represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Or, if style includes F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier:
[ws]hexdigits[ws]
Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: Optional white space if permitted by style.
An optional sign.
A sequence of digits from 0 through 9.
A sequence of hexadecimal digits from 0 through f, or 0 through F.

content.para: The provider parameter is an T:System.IFormatProvider that obtains a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo. The T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo provides culture-specific information about the format of s. If provider is null, the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture is used.
The following example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number in a specified culture-specific format to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.
An T:System.IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information about s.

returnValue.para: A 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent to the number specified in s.

content.para: s is null.
s is not in the correct format.
s represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Items in square brackets ('[' and ']') are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: Optional white space.
An optional positive sign.
A sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9.

content.para: The provider parameter is an T:System.IFormatProvider that obtains a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo. The T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo provides culture-specific information about the format of s. If provider is null, the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture is used.
The following example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of a sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9, without a sign or leading zeroes.

content.para: The return value is formatted with the general format specifier ("G") and the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.
Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.
Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified culture-specific format information.

content.para: An T:System.IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by provider.

content.para: This instance is formatted with the general format specifier ("G").

The provider parameter is an T:System.IFormatProvider that obtains a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo. The T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo provides culture-specific format information about this instance. If provider is null, this instance is formatted with the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified format.

content.para: A format specification.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by format.

content.para: The format parameter is invalid.
If format is null or an empty string (""), the return value of this instance is formatted with the general format specifier ("G").
The return value of this instance is formatted with the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified format and culture-specific format information.

content.para: A format specification.
An T:System.IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information about this instance.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by format and provider.

content.para: format is invalid.
If format is null or an empty string (""), the return value is formatted with the general format specifier ("G").

The provider parameter is an T:System.IFormatProvider instance that obtains a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo. The T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo provides culture-specific format information about this instance. If provider is null, the return value is formatted with the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo for the current culture.
The following example demonstrates the M:System.UInt16.ToString method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.

Converts the string representation of a number in a specified style and culture-specific format to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.
A bitwise combination of T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles values that indicates the permitted format of s. A typical value to specify is F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.Integer.
An T:System.IFormatProvider object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about s.

When this method returns, contains the 16-bit unsigned integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in a format compliant with style, or represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

returnValue.para: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

content.para: style is not a T:System.Globalization.NumberStyles value.
-or-
style is not a combination of F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier and F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.HexNumber values.

The M:System.UInt16.TryParse(System.String,System.UInt16@) method is like the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method, except the M:System.UInt16.TryParse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider,System.UInt16@) method does not throw an exception if the conversion fails.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Or, if the style parameter includes F:System.Globalization.NumberStyles.AllowHexSpecifier:
[ws]hexdigits[ws]
Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: Optional white space if permitted by style.
An optional sign.
A sequence of digits from 0 through 9.
A sequence of hexadecimal digits from 0 through f, or 0 through F.

content.para: The provider parameter is an T:System.IFormatProvider object that obtains a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo object. The T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo object provides culture-specific information about the format of s. If the provider parameter is null, the T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo object for the current culture is used.
The following code example demonstrates overloads of the Overload:System.UInt16.TryParse method for several base types, and the Overload:System.DateTime.TryParseExact method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
Converts the string representation of a number to its 16-bit unsigned integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.

content.para: A string representing the number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the 16-bit unsigned integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in the correct format. , or represents a number less than F:System.UInt16.MinValue or greater than F:System.UInt16.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

returnValue.para: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

content.para: The M:System.UInt16.TryParse(System.String,System.UInt16@) method is like the M:System.UInt16.Parse(System.String) method, except the M:System.UInt16.TryParse(System.String,System.UInt16@) method does not throw an exception if the conversion fails.
The s parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Items in square brackets ('[' and ']') are optional, and other items are as follows.

definition.para: An optional white space.
An optional positive sign.
A sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9.

content.para: The s parameter is parsed using the formatting information in a T:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo object initialized for the current system culture. For more information, see P:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo.CurrentInfo.
The following code example demonstrates overloads of the Overload:System.UInt16.TryParse method for several base types, and the Overload:System.DateTime.TryParseExact method.
